titleStmt.title: M1-8. 3 of 8. [Anon: For the long poem is luminous, radiant...]. Holograph. In [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 106-134. 15p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8. 3 of 8. [Anon: For the long poem is luminous, radiant...]. Holograph. In [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 106-134. 15p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: For a the long poem is lit up luminous, irradi radiant.
Yet Spenser standing on the threshold of the great
room is half in shadow half in light. He is not a

l.del: fully realised: it He is still anonymous, He in that he
does not embody confine emotions to the give

p.l: is still anonymous, in that he cannot confine
emotions within one place. He must symbolise;
exteriorise: jealousy is not a passion to be spoken;
He cannot convey jealousy by the speaking voice He must
make jealousy an actual words from an actual
mouth. He must make jealousy abstract, a symbol.

He ignores cannot cannot speak
thro' through the mouth of the
individual. The single is still in shadow. Yet, the other half of him is in the
light He is aware of his [ancestors?] as Chaucer was not, nor
Langland, nor Malory. His is no longer a wandering voice,

but the voice of a man
praitig practising an art, asking for
recognition,, resenting his & bitterly cautious of
de his own that the world of the world's scorn
Had to the common voice, the voice of the
English commoner, the mummer, the maker, the man at the
back door – Spenser had heard it–––
It was at half past two in the afternoon,
that the trumpets sounded & the flag went up on the
& the audience paid their audience accumulated. The
playhouse was open to the sky. The audience paid
a penny or twopence. They crowded the The playhouse was
the walls were painted; there was no scenery; but the
players were nobly dressed, according to one spectator, in
the cast off robes of the nobles sold by their servants.

upon the return upon the splendour of Tamburlaine:

quote.l: Brother Cosroe, I find myself much aggrieved
Yet insufficient to express the same;
For it requires a great & thundering speech:

p.l: The silence is broken; at last the voice speaks [fi?]
It It The Kings & Emperors are on the stage.
The world is made visible the
For us This is a play fanned by some
extraordinary [hearts?] into being – an
huperbole hyperbole , a [illeg.]: at last, there is
every life, complete, beat beating behind And the
mounting image, the wind & [illeg.], still blow out
the speech, even in the printed book.
There is The It is crude. The poet is anonymous.
This And yet what a All is now spoken by
each actor. There are no abstractions.
All is realised: the pomp & the masks & the
great swollen figures; as if Nothing is left
lurking in the shades. Still Even The figures are
palpable, coloured, strident. Is it
something has set in motion, not knights & ladies,
but the crude, jagged outlines of real
men. [And for?] there is a bombast & a splendour,
the great painted wigs & their [illeg.] [logs?]
are as still damp, un carved. Laughter,
like great moths brought by the [illeg.]:
But It is momentuous, [naked?]; resonant:
And the great names clash like brass.
Resound & [comedy?] No one is delicately
depicted. There is no shadow: but
all is gold & purple. And yet
the [currency?], the trumpets, fill the words: the
[abeard?], the huperbole hyperbole : this is a mood, a
splendid rhapsody: filled blown like a
with [folio?], in their [hur?], in suffering; but
yet – for there is no quarter, no stalling;

another & yet, for all its stridency, its

p.l: pomp, all the height of splendour, how
the poet can cut a gash in the fabric:

quote.l: And tis a pretty thing to be a poet

p.l: Could he stop, he would suffer. But there is no
[poem?], no shade as he travels. The [assess?]
And yet the tragic motive is broods over their
[acts?] & trampling vanguards; over their multitudes
confusion & splendour. Are we not entranced into a
sense of tragedy with tremendous clash &? Do we not foretell the
[funereal?] [illeg.]? Such tremendous blows
the smiling & the kneeling king, the pride of the
rampant emperor knock. And they,
as in in the [hoal?] [timely?] at one moment
still and heavy from the [firmament?] into
press of their [being] & splendour we hear:
this art is keeping somehow: a break in the
[struggle?]; a sign that the auth dramatist
is separating from the anonymous play maker:
a sign that there is as yet no little
language: so that he cannot amalgamate
[flow?] naturally; from the diction from
rhetoric, & speak, with simply.
Marlowe was swept away by his characters.
For, the audience, the shopkeepers, soldiers, [align?]
crowding to the stage, f spurred
spurr implored not [stillness?], but movement,
[illeg.]. We The play is still
partly the work of the audience: of the
undifferentiated mass. It is not yet a
separate book. It is imprinted by the common
voice, demanding great names, many
multitudes, a whole clamour on
stage, not reflection, not the brooding
subtlety of one soul. An orgy, a
[shapioly?], a spendid [illeg.]:
our souls, whose
faculties can
comprehend,
The wonderous
architecture of the
world,
And measure
every wandering
planet's
course,
Still climbing
after
knowledge infinite
Will us to
wear ourselves
& never
[rest?] ––
our souls are still the souls of many;
& so the single statement falls out of place
It is as if he was trying to do two things at the same time.
It is [irrelevant?]: a poem; a break; a mixture of two different [illeg.]
He was making it possible for the commoners & the

p.l: to listen to the same play. Before Spenser died the
playhouse was built, in which the mummers & the
[madrigals?] gave a lodging to the wandering actors;
their lodging, their centre.
It was open to the air. The It was
surrounded by [palings?]; half open to the air; it
for one penny was charged for standing room in the yard.

Next door to the Rose in Southwark stood
a brothel. Hogs infested the streets. The house itself
was built of wood; the roof was thatched; &
a flag flew when the time play was when the

Wh They flocked to the play What other was

No name was attached to Tamburlaine anonymous.
The play was anonymous. That fact by itself
is enough to show how largely the play was still
the work of inspired a common product.
detached from the author, unclaimed, as they made
a common product, shaped written by one hand, but
so moulded in its transition from the written word
to the spoken that the author had no sense of
propriety in it. Thus, when we If we
Yet the audience itself is dumb. We
They flocked to the play. They The
Fifteen hundred people, the main part apprentices, citizens,
heard Tamburlane; but for they say but one in silence word.

The silence of the
Ethn Elizabethan audience is one of the

If To understand that silence we have to
compare it with our own sense of something
that takes the breath away, is emerging, is
natural, is [illeg.] released, yet
uncritical – The attitude say of our own

surprisingly that we sit silent,
